links.title: ST. GIGA by matonao
links.description:
Translation (via Google):

This year's summer solstice coincided with a new moon, and there was also a solar eclipse, so it was very powerful, and my consciousness rose high in the sky to a satellite-like place. Before I knew it, I was searching for "St.GIGA" on YouTube.

St. Giga. How many people remember it now? Satellite radio broadcasting began on March 31, 1991, when WOWOW started broadcasting. It was an audio broadcast using two of WOWOW's remaining bands, and you turned on the TV and listened to the sound on a completely black screen.

At that time in Japan, satellite broadcasting was a special thing that had just started.

Since televisions were only in the living room, when I retired from club activities in my third year of junior high school, I spent the time until my mother came home from her part-time job in the living room in my uniform, listening to St.GIGA. I was aware that I was fascinated by something, but I couldn't tell anyone.

"I'm here. I'm glad you are there. We are St. Giga. This is St. Giga."

"The sun has just set on Rebun Island."

The sound of the waves, splashing, splashing. Music that sounds like the universe arrives from a satellite.

Broadcasts follow a "Tide Table" rather than a Time Table, and in the flow of time that is 24 hours long, the waves rise and fall in ecstasy with the tides.

When I look back on it as an adult, I realize that the background to the station's opening was the lingering scent of the bubble economy.
When WOWOW planned to welcome the late Hiroshi Yokoi, who was involved in the launch of J-WAVE, and create a stylish broadcasting station with the remaining bandwidth, Yokoi brought a thick, otherworldly proposal for broadcasting based on this "Tide Table" (the proposal was later published as a book titled "Tides of Dreams").
The proposal was approved as it was being planned by him, and it was assumed that there could be no mistake. Thus, this extremely avant-garde (I'm not sure if that's the right word) broadcasting station was born.

The sounds of waves and nature weave in between what would now be called ambient and healing music, and the sound never stops. All that was heard was a minimal narration that sounded like a signal from a spaceship.
Apparently Towa Tei was in charge of music selections for the entire day, so it must have been a meaningful broadcast for music fans (although I didn't really understand that).
Also, when the tide was high, they often played uplifting techno and trance music, and when I later learned about the concept of "chilling out," I felt like I was checking my memory of St.GIGA rather than my experience of going to a club.

For a few months after the station's launch, it was a non-scrambled broadcast, along with WOWOW, so I was able to listen to it, but it was a paid broadcast, albeit cheap. I remember very well the moment WOWOW was scrambled. I could no longer listen to St.GIGA, except for certain times of the day.
Even when I occasionally tuned in when it became a non-scrambled broadcast, by that time there was already a clear timetable, and the broadcast was not much different from stylish FM or cable.
There were no commercials or song introductions, and there was no way the cutting-edge broadcast at the time of its launch could make a profit. Please refer to wiki for details of the process up until the end of the broadcast.

However, for a long time, there were a very small number of people who pursued the "True Sound Trend" program from the beginning with a great deal of enthusiasm. St.GIGA extremists.

There may be quite a few people who remember it as a soothing broadcast, but it had a clearly different feeling from the sounds of waves and nature that are countless times downloaded on YouTube.
This is because it was a broadcast that actively sought to learn that "far away from our trivial lives, somewhere on Earth, somewhere in the universe, time is still flowing on a different scale." It was not on-demand. It was a sound that rained down from the universe according to the laws of that moment.
It is similar to what Michio Hoshino says about the moment when a polar bear wakes up from hibernation and comes out of its hole, and the awareness that the world of a humpback whale jumping up in the northern seas exists at the same time.
It was definitely "reached" from somewhere with a will. It felt like the first time you received an e-mail.
It was like peering into the abyss, and frightening to me as a 14-year-old.

Now, when I listen to the music of St.GIGA that remains on YouTube, the image of the gloomy Sea of ‚Äã‚ÄãJapan comes to my mind.
When I was a middle school student and was fascinated by this station, I didn't have to think of Alaska or Rebun Island; within cycling distance was the stormy Sea of ‚Äã‚ÄãJapan, where no one could reach.
Even back then, I think I had the sense that another timeline existed nearby, that "next to my life where I go to school and watch TV, there is another world beyond the reach of humans."
If I hadn't spent my middle school years in a remote area near the sea, I wouldn't have been so fascinated by it.

I wonder if such a station will appear again in 2020.
Now that anyone can broadcast, I wonder if a DJ or someone skilled in music and music production will have a channel.
Or, I wonder if an inn, cafe, or space that follows the laws of nature, similar to Tide Table, will be born.
If you go there and listen carefully, you can be actively aware of another timeline.

There seems to be nothing I can do, but I wonder if there is something I can do, I thought to myself around the summer solstice of 2020, a member of the St.GIGA adolescent group.

*Side note 1
Soon after I started working, when I was involved in a job for an audio magazine, I unintentionally met one of the people who recorded the natural sounds of St.GIGA in the field. 20 years ago, audio manufacturers still had the capacity to have such people and valuable sound sources. He said, "This person understands what St.GIGA is talking about! He talks quickly," and lent me his copy of "Dream Tides" (I was busy and it was difficult to read through. It's out of print, but I really want it now).

*Side note 2
When WOWOW first started broadcasting, there was a music program called "woo Music Satellite" hosted by Hiroshi Takano and Eri Fukatsu, and I watched it enthusiastically. This was four years before "Saturday Soliton Side-B" began broadcasting in 1995. "Side-B" is still talked about today, but for some reason not many people talk about "woo." I remember that they did something quite similar to Side-B earlier.
Takano was very moved by the idea of ‚Äã‚Äã"delivering music from a satellite" even back then, and he even created a song called "From Satellite With Love." St.GIGA was a bonus on wowow, but I feel that the worldview of the two is linked to each other.

links.description: Long before Switch Online, there was Satellaview for Nintendo‚Äôs Super Famicom, which is essentially a satellite modem. This Japan exclusive peripheral was released on April 23, 1995, and allowed users to access games, magazines, and more through satellite broadcasts provided by St.GIGA. How did it work? In addition to the Satellaview modem, users also needed a special broadcast satellite (BS) tuner that could either be purchased directly from St.GIGA or rented one for a six-month fee. links.title: The Waiting Room
links.description:
Simone Leigh
New Museum
June 22 ‚Äì September 18 2016

"In her work, Simone Leigh (b. 1968, Chicago, IL) demands that the concerns, roles, and rights of women of color be recognized as central, rather than pushed to the margins. Taking into account a history of social inequality that has necessitated community-organized care, traditionally provided by women, ‚ÄúSimone Leigh: The Waiting Room‚Äù considers the possibilities of disobedience, desire, and self-determination as they manifest in resistance to an imposed state of deferral and debasement. Whereas patience, pragmatism, and austerity often underscore political debates surrounding the failures of public health care, Leigh finds inspiration in parallel histories of urgency, agency, and intervention embraced by social movements, black communities, and women. Focusing specifically on an expanded notion of medicine, Leigh‚Äôs residency and exhibition at the New Museum reference a wide range of care environments and opportunities‚Äîfrom herbalist apothecaries, to muthi [medicine] markets in Durban, South Africa, to meditation rooms, to movement studios‚Äîand involve a variety of workshops and healing treatments that she refers to as ‚Äúcare sessions.‚Äù "

links.title: THE MIDDLE EAST CRISIS, STUDENT NONVIOLENT COORDINATING COMMITTEE, 1967
links.description:
What is considered SNCC‚Äôs Palestine Statement is actually an article published in the June-July 1967 SNCC Newsletter, shortly after the June 1967 Arab-Israeli War, under the title, ‚ÄúThird World Round Up: The Palestine Problem: Test Your Knowledge.‚Äù It was written by Ethel Minor, who was communications director at the time, and her primary source was a pamphlet published by the Palestine Research Center, called ‚ÄúDo You Know? Twenty Basic Facts about the Palestine Problem.‚Äù The article included illustrations by artist, Kofi Bailey.

Description via: https://snccdigital.org/inside-sncc/policy-statements/palestine/

links.title: Amerie / IG / 11.10.23
links.description:
The problem with the West is that it professes to be civilized (it is not, see, 'history) and it professes to have enlightened values of freedom, free speech, etc, but when pushed, when things get tough, all these things go out the window and we catch glimpse of
the fascist underpinnings that are always there. The West doesn't actually stand for anything at all. It has no moral center, no true north, no religion outside of money to center its people...it has nothing to guide it outside the everchanging whims of the
zeitgeist. The West stands behind nothing it espouses because it never meant any of it in the first place, which is why its so-called values cannot be relied upon during trying times. In the face of human tragedy of great scope, it's as if the West is seeing it for the first time, unable to glean wisdom from historical parallels. It doesn't see parallels because it cannot see past the
centering of itself.
The west is a hollow shell.
It's dead.
If it were ever truly alive.

links.description: Poet Nikki Giovanni was born in Knoxville, Tennessee, on June 7, 1943, and grew up in Cincinnati, Ohio. She graduated with a degree in history from Fisk University.
